Text: My weekly "Bringing the Capitol to You" emails are great for history buffs, students, and anyone with an interest in our American political institutions. You can share with friends and sign up here: https://t.co/8OgZWDO4eh

Historically, my office provides guided tours of the U.S. Capitol Building to Ohioans visiting Washington, D.C. However, due to the ongoing pause on public tours, I am giving Ohioans an opportunity a behind-the-scenes look at our seat of democracy – from home. https://t.co/eZHp1DeSNb

Bringing the Capitol to you:

Yesterday, the House passed a bill that I introduced to help tell their story by renaming the Burnet Avenue Post Office in Cincinnati after them. The building is located in the North Avondale neighborhood in which the two men went to school together.
https://t.co/BG40pYVlWi

The duo became fast friends and dedicated their later years to traveling the country to give talks to students about interracial understanding and unity. Their story became the topic of the book Black and White Airmen: Their True History and @Local12 Documentary "Side by Side."

John Leahr and Herbert Heilbrun were heroes who both served as pilots in the Army Air Corps during WWII. Later in life, they met and learned that they unknowingly flew on some of the same missions in the war, were both from Cincinnati, and even attended school together.

It was an honor to welcome Tri-State veterans who were making their Honor Flight to the WWII memorial. We owe them a debt of gratitude that cannot be repaid. Thank you to all our veterans for your service! https://t.co/xTBiBMFI9q

Recently, I introduced the bipartisan Patriot Retention Act to help alleviate this problem and provide our Armed Forces with additional tools to meet our personnel needs and provide a pathway for qualified, specialists to continue their service with the Ready Reserve. (2/3)

To that end, I will continue working to ensure that the No Surprises Act is implemented in line with congressional intent.
If unchanged, this rule will disincentivize insurance companies from keeping providers in their networks, limiting care for Americans and threatening the health and safety of our nation.

In June, I led 96 of my colleagues from both sides of the aisle in calling upon the administration to reflect congressional intent as they implemented these critical patient protections. Unfortunately, this rule does not meet our intent.
In crafting the legislation, Congress protected patients and created a balanced process to settle payment disputes between health care providers and insurers.

The HHS Second Rule on surprise billing is a disaster for patient access. Congress was very clear that we did not intend to create a de facto benchmark for negotiations when creating the arbitration process in the historic, bipartisan No Surprises Act.

Congress introduced critical legislation that the State Department said was needed to accelerate the process. Rep. Crow and I led the HOPE for Afghan SIVs Act. Rep Crow and the Working Group also introduced the ALLIES Act. HOPE and critical provisions of ALLIES became law.

In our June 4 letter, we expressed our concerns that there was not yet a whole of government plan to protect our Afghan partners, and we expressed our belief that “we must evacuate our Afghan friends and allies immediately.” https://t.co/OL0aK4TTyK
